column4: Alright, I give up....I can't get my command line to work...I'm trying to remove every zip except the file that I find using the following command line: find /var/www/its/tmp/ -maxdepth 0 -name test_mp4s.zip -prune -exec rm -f /var/www/its/*.zip '{}' ';'
This just removes every .zip file
there's a lot of ways to do it.  Maybe the easiest to follow: ls /path | grep -v test.zip | xargs rm
umm, ls /path/*.zip
do each part of the pipe seperately.  Start with: ls /path/*.zip.  Does that list all the zips?
okay, now ls /path/*.zip | grep -v oneToKeep.zip (the -v says "print everything EXCEPT that one")
including the one you want to keep?
okay, so add "|xargs rm" to the command, and that should delete the rest of them
ls -l /var/www/its/tmp/ | pastebinit
oh, the filenames have spaces in?
spaces in filenames are *evil*!
FOO=$(ls /path/*.zip|grep -v onetokeep.zip); for filename in "${FOO}"; do ls "${filename}; done
run that, make sure it outputs the right filenames, if it does then replace the second ls with rm
FOO=$(ls /path/*.zip|grep -v onetokeep.zip); for filename in "${FOO}"; do ls "${filename}"; done
but seriously...save yourself a LOT of pain.  Avoid spaces in filenames (if you can)
awesome, well done
remember, spaces in filenames are evil :)
it's pretty loigical, if I'd known there were spaces to start with we could have gond straight there :)

FOO=$(...) says "assign the output of the command in $(...) to the variable FOO.  for file in "${FOO}"...the "" around "${FOO}" stops bash from splitting words around spaces.  The rest shiould be self explanatory (but ask if you don't understand it)
then they're gone.  Sorry
and use /tmp for testing stuff.  mkdir /tmp/somewheretotest and then test in there
